First, let it be in that ratio to a less area .

Let the square  be inscribed in the circle ; then the inscribed square is greater than the half of the circle , inasmuch as, if through the points , , ,  we draw tangents to the circle, the square  is half the square circumscribed about the circle, and the circle is less than the circumscribed square; hence the inscribed square  is greater than the half of the circle .

Let the circumferences , , ,  be bisected at the points , , , , and let , , , , , , ,  be joined; therefore each of the triangles , , ,  is also greater than the half of the segment of the circle about it, inasmuch as, if through the points , , ,  we draw tangents to the circle and complete the parallelograms on the straight lines , , , , each of the triangles , , ,  will be half of the parallelogram about it, while the segment about it is less than the parallelogram; hence each of the triangles , , ,  is greater than the half of the segment of the circle about it.

Thus, by bisecting the remaining circumferences and joining straight lines, and by doing this continually, we shall leave some segments of the circle which will be less than the excess by which the circle  exceeds the area .

Therefore the remainder, the polygon , is greater than the area .
Let there be inscribed, also, in the circle  the polygon  similar to the polygon ; therefore, as the square on  is to the square on , so is the polygon  to the polygon . []

But, as the square on  is to the square on , so also is the circle  to the area ; therefore also, as the circle  is to the area , so is the polygon  to the polygon ; [] therefore, alternately, as the circle  is to the polygon inscribed in it, so is the area  to the polygon . []
But the circle  is greater than the polygon inscribed in it; therefore the area  is also greater than the polygon .

p: But it is also less: which is impossible.

p.#text: Therefore, as the square on  is to the square on , so is not the circle  to any area less than the circle .
Similarly we can prove that neither is the circle  to any area less than the circle  as the square on  is to the square on .
I say next that neither is the circle  to any area greater than the circle  as the square on  is to the square on .
For, if possible, let it be in that ratio to a greater area .
Therefore, inversely, as the square on  is to the square on , so is the area  to the circle .

But, as the area  is to the circle , so is the circle  to some area less than the circle ; therefore also, as the square on  is to the square on , so is the circle  to some area less than the circle : [] which was proved impossible.
Therefore, as the square on  is to the square on , so is not the circle  to any area greater than the circle .
And it was proved that neither is it in that ratio to any area less than the circle ; therefore, as the square on  is to the square on , so is the circle  to the circle .

p: Therefore etc. Q. E. D.

p.#text: I say that, the area  being greater than the circle , as the area  is to the circle , so is the circle  to some area less than the circle .
For let it be contrived that, as the area  is to the circle , so is the circle  to the area .
I say that the area  is less than the circle .
For since, as the area  is to the circle , so is the circle  to the area , therefore, alternately, as the area  is to the circle , so is the circle  to the area . []
But the area  is greater than the circle ; therefore the circle  is also greater than the area .
Hence, as the area  is to the circle , so is the circle  to some area less than the circle . Q. E. D.

hi.#text: Any pyramid which has a triangular base is divided into two pyramids equal and similar to one another
similar to the whole and having triangular bases
and into two equal prisms; and the two prisms are greater than the half of the whole pyramid.

p.#text: Let there be a pyramid of which the triangle  is the base and the point  the vertex; I say that the pyramid  is divided into two pyramids equal to one another, having triangular bases and similar to the whole pyramid, and into two equal prisms; and the two prisms are greater than the half of the whole pyramid.
For let , , , , ,  be bisected at the points , , , , , , and let , , , , , , ,  be joined.
Since  is equal to , and  to , therefore  is parallel to . []
For the same reason  is also parallel to .
Therefore  is a parallelogram; therefore  is equal to . []
But  is equal to ; therefore  is also equal to .
But  is also equal to ; therefore the two sides ,  are equal to the two sides ,  respectively, and the angle  is equal to the angle ; therefore the base  is equal to the base . []
Therefore the triangle  is equal and similar to the triangle .
For the same reason the triangle  is also equal and similar to the triangle .
Now, since two straight lines ,  meeting one another are parallel to two straight lines ,  meeting one another, and are not in the same plane, they will contain equal angles. []
Therefore the angle  is equal to the angle .

And, since the two straight lines ,  are equal to the two ,  respectively, and the angle  is equal to the angle , therefore the base  is equal to the base ; [] therefore the triangle  is equal and similar to the triangle .
For the same reason the triangle  is also equal and similar to the triangle .
Therefore the pyramid of which the triangle  is the base and the point  the vertex is equal and similar to the pyramid of which the triangle  is the base and the point  the vertex. []

And, since  has been drawn parallel to , one of the sides of the triangle , the triangle  is equiangular to the triangle , [] and they have their sides proportional; therefore the triangle  is similar to the triangle . []
For the same reason the triangle  is also similar to the triangle , and the triangle  to the triangle .
Now, since the two straight lines ,  meeting one another are parallel to the two straight lines ,  meeting one another, not in the same plane, they will contain equal angles. []
Therefore the angle  is equal to the angle .
And, as  is to , so is  to ; therefore the triangle  is similar to the triangle .
Therefore also the pyramid of which the triangle  is the base and the point  the vertex is similar to the pyramid of which the triangle  is the base and the point  the vertex.
But the pyramid of which the triangle  is the base and the point  the vertex was proved similar to the pyramid of which the triangle  is the base and the point  the vertex.
Therefore each of the pyramids ,  is similar to the whole pyramid .
Next, since  is equal to , the parallelogram  is double of the triangle .

And since, if there be two prisms of equal height, and one have a parallelogram as base, and the other a triangle, and if the parallelogram be double of the triangle, the prisms are equal, [] therefore the prism contained by the two triangles , , and the three parallelograms , ,  is equal to the prism contained by the two triangles ,  and the three parallelograms , , .

And it is manifest that each of the prisms, namely that in which the parallelogram  is the base and the straight line  is its opposite, and that in which the triangle  is the base and the triangle  its opposite, is greater than each of the pyramids of which the triangles ,  are the bases and the points ,  the vertices, inasmuch as, if we join the straight lines , , the prism in which the parallelogram  is the base and the straight line  its opposite is greater than the pyramid of which the triangle  is the base and the point  the vertex.

But the pyramid of which the triangle  is the base and the point  the vertex is equal to the pyramid of which the triangle  is the base and the point  the vertex; for they are contained by equal and similar planes.
Hence also the prism in which the parallelogram  is the base and the straight line  its opposite is greater than the pyramid of which the triangle  is the base and the point  the vertex.

But the prism in which the parallelogram  is the base and the straight line  its opposite is equal to the prism in which the triangle  is the base and the triangle  its opposite, and the pyramid of which the triangle  is the base and the point  the vertex is equal to the pyramid of which the triangle  is the base and the point  the vertex.
Therefore the said two prisms are greater than the said two pyramids of which the triangles ,  are the bases and the points ,  the vertices.

Therefore the whole pyramid, of which the triangle  is the base and the point  the vertex, has been divided into two pyramids equal to one another and into two equal prisms, and the two prisms are greater than the half of the whole pyramid. Q. E. D.

hi.#text: If there be two pyramids of the same height which have triangular bases
and cach of them be divided into two pyramids equal to one another and similar to the whole, and into two equal prisms
as the base of the one pyramid is to the base of the other pyramid
so will all the prisms in the one pyramid be to all the prisms

p.#text: Let there be two pyramids of the same height which have the triangular bases , , and vertices the points , , and let each of them be divided into two pyramids equal to one another and similar to the whole and into two equal prisms; [] I say that, as the base  is to the base , so are all the prisms in the pyramid  to all the prisms, being equal in multitude, in the pyramid ,
For, since  is equal to , and  to , therefore  is parallel to , and the triangle  is similar to the triangle .
For the same reason the triangle  is also similar to the triangle .
And, since  is double of , and  of , therefore, as  is to , so is  to .

And on ,  are described the similar and similarly situated rectilineal figures , , and on ,  the similar and similarly situated figures , ; therefore, as the triangle  is to the triangle , so is the triangle  to the triangle ; [] therefore, alternately, as the triangle  is to the triangle , so is the triangle  to the triangle . []

But, as the triangle  is to the triangle , so is the prism in which the triangle  is the base and  its opposite to the prism in which the triangle  is the base and  its opposite; [Lemma following] therefore also, as the triangle  is to the triangle , so is the prism in which the triangle  is the base and  its opposite to the prism in which the triangle  is the base and  its opposite.

But, as the said prisms are to one another, so is the prism in which the parallelogram  is the base and the straight line  its opposite to the prism in which the parallelogram  is the base and the straight line  its opposite. [; cf. ]

Therefore also the two prisms, that in which the parallelogram  is the base and  its opposite, and that in which the triangle  is the base and  its opposite, are to the prisms in which  is the base and the straight line  its opposite and in which the triangle  is the base and  its opposite in the same ratio []
Therefore also, as the base  is to the base , so are the said two prisms to the said two prisms.
And similarly, if the pyramids ,  be divided into two prisms and two pyramids, as the base  is to the base , so will the two prisms in the pyramid  be to the two prisms in the pyramid .
But, as the base  is to the base , so is the base  to the base ; for the triangles ,  are equal to the triangles ,  respectively.
Therefore also, as the base  is to the base , so are the four prisms to the four prisms.

And similarly also, if we divide the remaining pyramids into two pyramids and into two prisms, then, as the base  is to the base , so will all the prisms in the pyramid  be to all the prisms, being equal in multitude, in the pyramid . Q. E. D.

But that, as the triangle  is to the triangle , so is the prism in which the triangle  is the base and  its opposite to the prism in which the triangle  is the base and  its opposite, we must prove as follows.
For in the same figure let perpendiculars be conceived drawn from ,  to the planes , ; these are of course equal because, by hypothesis, the pyramids are of equal height.
Now, since the two straight lines  and the perpendicular from  are cut by the parallel planes , , they will be cut in the same ratios. []
And  is bisected by the plane  at ; therefore the perpendicular from  to the plane  will also be bisected by the plane .
For the same reason the perpendicular from  to the plane  will also be bisected by the plane .
And the perpendiculars from ,  to the planes ,  are equal; therefore the perpendiculars from the triangles ,  to the planes ,  are also equal.
Therefore the prisms in which the triangles ,  are bases, and ,  their opposites, are of equal height.

Hence also the parallelepipedal solids described from the said prisms are of equal height and are to one another as their bases; [] therefore their halves, namely the said prisms, are to one another as the base  is to the base . Q. E. D.

div3.head: PROPOSITION 5.

hi.#text: Pyramids which are of the same height and have triangular bases are to one another as the bases.

p.#text: Let there be pyramids of the same height, of which the triangles ,  are the bases and the points ,  the vertices; I say that, as the base  is to the base , so is the pyramid  to the pyramid .
For, if the pyramid  is not to the pyramid  as the base  is to the base , then, as the base  is to the base , so will the pyramid  be either to some solid less than the pyramid  or to a greater.

Let it, first, be in that ratio to a less solid , and let the pyramid  be divided into two pyramids equal to one another and similar to the whole and into two equal prisms; then the two prisms are greater than the half of the whole pyramid. []

Again, let the pyramids arising from the division be similarly divided, and let this be done continually until there are left over from the pyramid  some pyramids which are less than the excess by which the pyramid  exceeds the solid . [X. I]
Let such be left, and let them be, for the sake of argument, , ; therefore the remainders, the prisms in the pyramid , are greater than the solid .

Let the pyramid  also be divided similarly, and a similar number of times, with the pyramid ; therefore, as the base  is to the base , so are the prisms in the pyramid  to the prisms in the pyramid . []

But, as the base  is to the base , so also is the pyramid  to the solid ; therefore also, as the pyramid  is to the solid , so are the prisms in the pyramid  to the prisms in the pyramid ; [V. II] therefore, alternately, as the pyramid  is to the prisms in it, so is the solid  to the prisms in the pyramid . []
But the pyramid  is greater than the prisms in it; therefore the solid  is also greater than the prisms in the pyramid .

p: But it is also less: which is impossible.

p.#text: Therefore the prism  is not to any solid less than the pyramid  as the base  is to the base .
Similarly it can be proved that neither is the pyramid  to any solid less than the pyramid  as the base  is to the base .
I say next that neither is the pyramid  to any solid greater than the pyramid  as the base  is to the base .
For, if possible, let it be in that ratio to a greater solid ; therefore, inversely, as the base  is to the base , so is the solid  to the pyramid .

But, as the solid  is to the solid , so is the pyramid  to some solid less than the pyramid , as was before proved; [] therefore also, as the base  is to the base , so is the pyramid  to some solid less than the pyramid : [V. II] which was proved absurd.
Therefore the pyramid  is not to any solid greater than the pyramid  as the base  is to the base .

p: But it was proved that neither is it in that ratio to a less solid.

p.#text: Therefore, as the base  is to the base , so is the pyramid  to the pyramid . Q. E. D.

hi.#text: Pyramids which are of the same height and have polygonal bases are to one another as the bases.

p.#text: Let there be pyramids of the same height of which the polygons ,  are the bases and the points ,  the vertices; I say that, as the base  is to the base , so is the pyramid  to the pyramid .
For let , , ,  be joined.
Since then ,  are two pyramids which have triangular bases and equal height, they are to one another as the bases; [] therefore, as the base  is to the base , so is the pyramid  to the pyramid .
And, , as the base  is to the base , so is the pyramid  to the pyramid . []
But also, as the base  is to the base , so is the pyramid  to the pyramid . []
Therefore, , as the base  is to the base , so is the pyramid  to the pyramid . []
And again , as the base  is to the base , so is the pyramid  to the pyramid . []
Similarly also it can be proved that, as the base  is to the base , so is the pyramid  to the pyramid .
And, since ,  are two pyramids which have triangular bases and equal height, therefore, as the base  is to the base , so is the pyramid  to the pyramid . []
But, as the base  is to the base , so was the pyramid  to the pyramid .
Therefore also, , as the base  is to the base , so is the pyramid  to the pyramid . []
But further, as the base  is to the base , so also was the pyramid  to the pyramid .
Therefore also, , as the base  is to the base , so is the pyramid  to the pyramid . [] Q. E. D.

hi.#text: Any prism which has a triangular base is divided into three pyramids equal to one another which have triangular bases.

p.#text: Let there be a prism in which the triangle  is the base and  its opposite; I say that the prism  is divided into three pyramids equal to one another, which have triangular bases.
For let , ,  be joined.

Since  is a parallelogram, and  is its diameter, therefore the triangle  is equal to the triangle ; [] therefore also the pyramid of which the triangle  is the base and the point  the vertex is equal to the pyramid of which the triangle  is the base and the point  the vertex. []

But the pyramid of which the triangle  is the base and the point  the vertex is the same with the pyramid of which the triangle  is the base and the point  the vertex; for they are contained by the same planes.
Therefore the pyramid of which the triangle  is the base and the point  the vertex is also equal to the pyramid of which the triangle  is the base and the point  the vertex.
Again, since  is a parallelogram, and  is its diameter, the triangle  is equal to the triangle . []
Therefore also the pyramid of which the triangle  is the base and the point  the vertex is equal to the pyramid of which the triangle  is the base and the point  the vertex. []

But the pyramid of which the triangle  is the base and the point  the vertex was proved equal to the pyramid of which the triangle  is the base and the point  the vertex; therefore also the pyramid of which the triangle  is the base and the point  the vertex is equal to the pyramid of which the triangle  is the base and the point  the vertex; therefore the prism  has been divided into three pyramids equal to one another which have triangular bases.

And, since the pyramid of which the triangle  is the base and the point  the vertex is the same with the pyramid of which the triangle  is the base and the point  the vertex, for they are contained by the same planes, while the pyramid of which the triangle  is the base and the point  the vertex was proved to be a third of the prism in which the triangle  is the base and  its opposite, therefore also the pyramid of which the triangle  is the base and the point  the vertex is a third of the prism which has the same base, the triangle , and  as its opposite.

div4.head: PORISM.
div4.p: From this it is manifest that any pyramid is a third part of the prism which has the same base with it and equal height. Q. E. D.

hi.#text: Similar pyramids which have triangular bases are in the triplicate ratio of their corresponding sides.

p.#text: Let there be similar and similarly situated pyramids of which the triangles , , are the bases and the points ,  the vertices; I say that the pyramid  has to the pyramid  the ratio triplicate of that which  has to .
For let the parallelepipedal solids ,  be completed.
Now, since the pyramid  is similar to the pyramid , therefore the angle  is equal to the angle , the angle  to the angle , and the angle  to the angle ; and, as  is to , so is  to , and  to .
And since, as  is to , so is  to , and the sides are proportional about equal angles, therefore the parallelogram  is similar to the parallelogram .
For the same reason  is also similar to , and  to ; therefore the three parallelograms , ,  are similar to the three , , .
But the three parallelograms , ,  are equal and similar to their three opposites, and the three , ,  are equal and similar to their three opposites. []
Therefore the solids ,  are contained by similar planes equal in multitude.
Therefore the solid  is similar to the solid .
But similar parallelepipedal solids are in the triplicate ratio of their corresponding sides. []
Therefore the solid  has to the solid  the ratio triplicate of that which the corresponding side  has to the corresponding side .

But, as the solid  is to the solid , so is the pyramid  to the pyramid , inasmuch as the pyramid is a sixth part of the solid, because the prism which is half of the parallelepipedal solid [] is also triple of the pyramid. []
Therefore the pyramid  also has to the pyramid  the ratio triplicate of that which  has to . Q. E. D.

div4.head: PORISM.
p: From this it is manifest that similar pyramids which have polygonal bases are also to one another in the triplicate ratio of their corresponding sides.

p.#text: For, if they are divided into the pyramids contained in them which have triangular bases, by virtue of the fact that the similar polygons forming their bases are also divided into similar triangles equal in multitude and corresponding to the wholes [], then, as the one pyramid which has a triangular base in the one complete pyramid is to the one pyramid which has a triangular base in the other complete pyramid, so also will all the pyramids which have triangular bases contained in the one pyramid be to all the pyramids which have triangular bases contained in the other pyramid [], that is, the pyramid itself which has a polygonal base to the pyramid which has a polygonal base.

p: But the pyramid which has a triangular base is to the pyramid which has a triangular base in the triplicate ratio of the corresponding sides; therefore also the pyramid which has a polygonal base has to the pyramid which has a similar base the ratio triplicate of that which the side has to the side.

div3.head: PROPOSITION 9.

hi.#text: In equal pyramids which have triangular bases the bases are reciprocally proportional to the heights; and those pyramids in which the bases are reciprocally proportional to the heights are equal.

p.#text: For let there be equal pyramids which have the triangular bases ,  and vertices the points , ; I say that in the pyramids ,  the bases are reciprocally proportional to the heights, that is, as the base  is to the base , so is the height of the pyramid  to the height of the pyramid .
For let the parallelepipedal solids ,  be completed.
Now, since the pyramid  is equal to the pyramid , and the solid  is six times the pyramid , and the solid  six times the pyramid , therefore the solid  is equal to the solid .
But in equal parallelepipedal solids the bases are reciprocally proportional to the heights; [] therefore, as the base  is to the base , so is the height of the solid  to the height of the solid .
But, as the base  is to , so is the triangle  to the triangle . []
Therefore also, as the triangle  is to the triangle , so is the height of the solid  to the height of the solid . []

But the height of the solid  is the same with the height of the pyramid , and the height of the solid  is the same with the height of the pyramid , therefore, as the base  is to the base , so is the height of the pyramid  to the height of the pyramid .
Therefore in the pyramids ,  the bases are reciprocally proportional to the heights.

Next, in the pyramids ,  let the bases be reciprocally proportional to the heights; that is, as the base  is to the base , so let the height of the pyramid  be to the height of the pyramid ; I say that the pyramid  is equal to the pyramid .

For, with the same construction, since, as the base  is to the base , so is the height of the pyramid  to the height of the pyramid , while, as the base  is to the base , so is the parallelogram  to the parallelogram , therefore also, as the parallelogram  is to the parallelogram , so is the height of the pyramid  to the height of the pyramid . []

But the height of the pyramid  is the same with the height of the parallelepiped , and the height of the pyramid  is the same with the height of the parallelepiped ; therefore, as the base  is to the base , so is the height of the parallelepiped  to the height of the parallelepiped .
But those parallelepipedal solids in which the bases are reciprocally proportional to the heights are equal; [] therefore the parallelepipedal solid  is equal to the parallelepipedal solid .
And the pyramid  is a sixth part of , and the pyramid  a sixth part of the parallelepiped ; therefore the pyramid  is equal to the pyramid .

p: Therefore etc Q. E. D.

div3.head: PROPOSITION 10.

hi.#text: Any cone is a third part of the cylinder which has the same base with it and equal height.

p.#text: For let a cone have the same base, namely the circle , with a cylinder and equal height; I say that the cone is a third part of the cylinder, that is, that the cylinder is triple of the cone.
For if the cylinder is not triple of the cone, the cylinder will be either greater than triple or less than triple of the cone.
First let it be greater than triple, and let the square  be inscribed in the circle ; [] then the square  is greater than the half of the circle .
From the square  let there be set up a prism of equal height with the cylinder.

Then the prism so set up is greater than the half of the cylinder, inasmuch as, if we also circumscribe a square about the circle  [], the square inscribed in the circle  is half of that circumscribed about it, and the solids set up from them are parallelepipedal prisms of equal height, while parallelepipedal solids which are of the same height are to one another as their bases; [] therefore also the prism set up on the square  is half of the prism set up from the square circumscribed about the circle ; [cf. , or ] and the cylinder is less than the prism set up from the square circumscribed about the circle ; therefore the prism set up from the square  and of equal height with the cylinder is greater than the half of the cylinder.

Let the circumferences , , ,  be bisected at the points , , , , and let , , , , , , ,  be joined; then each of the triangles , , ,  is greater than the half of that segment of the circle  which is about it, as we proved before. []

On each of the triangles , , ,  let prisms be set up of equal height with the cylinder; then each of the prisms so set up is greater than the half part of that segment of the cylinder which is about it, inasmuch as, if we draw through the points , , ,  parallels to , , , , complete the parallelograms on , , , , and set up from them parallelepipedal solids of equal height with the cylinder, the prisms on the triangles , , ,  are halves of the several solids set up; and the segments of the cylinder are less than the parallelepipedal solids set up; hence also the prisms on the triangles , , ,  are greater than the half of the segments of the cylinder about them.

Thus, bisecting the circumferences that are left, joining straight lines, setting up on each of the triangles prisms of equal height with the cylinder, and doing this continually, we shall leave some segments of the cylinder which will be less than the excess by which the cylinder exceeds the triple of the cone. []

Let such segments be left, and let them be , , , , , , , ; therefore the remainder, the prism of which the polygon  is the base and the height is the same as that of the cylinder, is greater than triple of the cone.

But the prism of which the polygon  is the base and the height the same as that of the cylinder is triple of the pyramid of which the polygon  is the base and the vertex is the same as that of the cone; [] therefore also the pyramid of which the polygon  is the base and the vertex is the same as that of the cone is greater than the cone which has the circle  as base.

p: But it is also less, for it is enclosed by it: which is impossible.
Therefore the cylinder is not greater than triple of the cone.
I say next that neither is the cylinder less than triple of the cone,
For, if possible, let the cylinder be less than triple of the cone, therefore, inversely, the cone is greater than a third part of the cylinder.

p.#text: Let the square  be inscribed in the circle ; therefore the square  is greater than the half of the circle .

Now let there be set up from the square  a pyramid having the same vertex with the cone; therefore the pyramid so set up is greater than the half part of the cone, seeing that, as we proved before, if we circumscribe a square about the circle, the square  will be half of the square circumscribed about the circle, and if we set up from the squares parallelepipedal solids of equal height with the cone, which are also called prisms, the solid set up from the square  will be half of that set up from the square circumscribed about the circle; for they are to one another as their bases. []
Hence also the thirds of them are in that ratio; therefore also the pyramid of which the square  is the base is half of the pyramid set up from the square circumscribed about the circle.

p: And the pyramid set up from the square about the circle is greater than the cone, for it encloses it.

p.#text: Therefore the pyramid of which the square  is the base and the vertex is the same with that of the cone is greater than the half of the cone.

Let the circumferences , , ,  be bisected at the points , , , , and let , , , , , , ,  be joined; therefore also each of the triangles , , ,  is greater than the half part of that segment of the circle  which is about it.

Now, on each of the triangles , , ,  let pyramids be set up which have the same vertex as the cone; therefore also each of the pyramids so set up is, in the same manner, greater than the half part of that segment of the cone which is about it.

Thus, by bisecting the circumferences that are left, joining straight lines, setting up on each of the triangles a pyramid which has the same vertex as the cone, and doing this continually, we shall leave some segments of the cone which will be less than the excess by which the cone exceeds the third part of the cylinder. []

Let such be left, and let them be the segments on , , , , , , , ; therefore the remainder, the pyramid of which the polygon  is the base and the vertex the same with that of the cone, is greater than a third part of the cylinder.

But the pyramid of which the polygon  is the base and the vertex the same with that of the cone is a third part of the prism of which the polygon  is the base and the height is the same with that of the cylinder; therefore the prism of which the polygon  is the base and the height is the same with that of the cylinder is greater than the cylinder of which the circle  is the base.

p: But it is also less, for it is enclosed by it: which is impossible.
Therefore the cylinder is not less than triple of the cone.
But it was proved that neither is it greater than triple; therefore the cylinder is triple of the cone; hence the cone is a third part of the cylinder.
Therefore etc. Q. E. D.

div3.head: PROPOSITION 11.

hi.#text: Cones and cylinders which are of the same height are to one another as their bases.

p.#text: Let there be cones and cylinders of the same height, let the circles ,  be their bases, ,  their axes and ,  the diameters of their bases; I say that, as the circle  is to the circle , so is the cone  to the cone .
For, if not, then, as the circle  is to the circle , so will the cone  be either to some solid less than the cone  or to a greater.
First, let it be in that ratio to a less solid , and let the solid  be equal to that by which the solid  is less than the cone ; therefore the cone  is equal to the solids , .
Let the square  be inscribed in the circle ; therefore the square is greater than the half of the circle.

Let there be set up from the square  a pyramid of equal height with the cone; therefore the pyramid so set up is greater than the half of the cone, inasmuch as, if we circumscribe a square about the circle, and set up from it a pyramid of equal height with the cone, the inscribed pyramid is half of the circumscribed pyramid, for they are to one another as their bases, [] while the cone is less than the circumscribed pyramid.
Let the circumferences , , ,  be bisected at the points , , , , and let , , , , , , ,  be joined.
Therefore each of the triangles , , ,  is greater than the half of that segment of the circle which is about it.

On each of the triangles , , ,  let there be set up a pyramid of equal height with the cone; therefore, also, each of the pyramids so set up is greater than the half of that segment of the cone which is about it.

Thus, bisecting the circumferences which are left, joining straight lines, setting up on each of the triangles pyramids of equal height with the cone, and doing this continually, we shall leave some segments of the cone which will be less than the solid . []

Let such be left, and let them be the segments on , , , , , , , ; therefore the remainder, the pyramid of which the polygon  is the base and the height the same with that of the cone, is greater than the solid .
Let there also be inscribed in the circle  the polygon  similar and similarly situated to the polygon , and on it let a pyramid be set up of equal height with the cone .

Since then, as the square on  is to the square on , so is the polygon  to the polygon , [] while, as the square on  is to the square on , so is the circle  to the circle , [] therefore also, as the circle  is to the circle , so is the polygon  to the polygon .

But, as the circle  is to the circle , so is the cone  to the solid , and, as the polygon  is to the polygon , so is the pyramid of which the polygon  is the base and the point  the vertex to the pyramid of which the polygon  is the base and the point  the vertex. []

Therefore also, as the cone  is to the solid , so is the pyramid of which the polygon  is the base and the point  the vertex to the pyramid of which the polygon  is the base and the point  the vertex; [] therefore, alternately, as the cone  is to the pyramid in it, so is the solid  to the pyramid in the cone . []
But the cone  is greater than the pyramid in it; therefore the solid  is also greater than the pyramid in the cone .

p: But it is also less: which is absurd.

p.#text: Therefore the cone  is not to any solid less than the cone  as the circle  is to the circle .
Similarly we can prove that neither is the cone  to any solid less than the cone  as the circle  is to the circle .
I say next that neither is the cone  to any solid greater than the cone  as the circle  is to the circle .
For, if possible, let it be in that ratio to a greater solid ; therefore, inversely, as the circle  is to the circle , so is the solid  to the cone .

But, as the solid  is to the cone , so is the cone  to some solid less than the cone ; therefore also, as the circle  is to the circle , so is the cone  to some solid less than the cone : which was proved impossible.
Therefore the cone  is not to any solid greater than the cone  as the circle  is to the circle .
But it was proved that neither is it in this ratio to a less solid; therefore, as the circle  is to the circle , so is the cone  to the cone .
But, as the cone is to the cone, so is the cylinder to the cylinder, for each is triple of each; []
Therefore also, as the circle  is to the circle , so are the cylinders on them which are of equal height.

p: Therefore etc. Q. E. D.

div3.head: PROPOSITION 12.

hi.#text: Similar cones and cylinders are to one another in the triplicate ratio of the diameters in their bases.

p.#text: Let there be similar cones and cylinders, let the circles ,  be their bases, ,  the diameters of the bases, and ,  the axes of the cones and cylinders; I say that the cone of which the circle  is the base and the point  the vertex has to the cone of which the circle  is the base and the point  the vertex the ratio triplicate of that which  has to .
For, if the cone  has not to the cone  the ratio triplicate of that which  has to , the cone  will have that triplicate ratio either to some solid less than the cone  or to a greater.
First, let it have that triplicate ratio to a less solid .
Let the square  be inscribed in the circle ; [] therefore the square  is greater than the half of the circle .
Now let there be set up on the square  a pyramid having the same vertex with the cone; therefore the pyramid so set up is greater than the half part of the cone.
Let the circumferences , , ,  be bisected at the points , , , , and let , , , , , , ,  be joined.
Therefore each of the triangles , , ,  is also greater than the half part of that segment of the circle  which is about it.

Now on each of the triangles , , ,  let a pyramid be set up having the same vertex with the cone; therefore each of the pyramids so set up is also greater than the half part of that segment of the cone which is about it.

Thus, bisecting the circumferences so left, joining straight lines, setting up on each of the triangles pyramids having the same vertex with the cone, and doing this continually, we shall leave some segments of the cone which will be less than the excess by which the cone  exceeds the solid . []
Let such be left, and let them be the segments on , , , , , , , ; therefore the remainder, the pyramid of which the polygon  is the base and the point  the vertex, is greater than the solid .

Let there be also inscribed in the circle  the polygon  similar and similarly situated to the polygon , and let there be set up on the polygon  a pyramid having the same vertex with the cone; of the triangles containing the pyramid of which the polygon  is the base and the point  the vertex let  be one, and of the triangles containing the pyramid of which the polygon  is the base and the point  the vertex let  be one; and let ,  be joined.
Now, since the cone  is similar to the cone , therefore, as  is to , so is the axis  to the axis . []
But, as  is to , so is  to ; therefore also, as  is to , so is  to .
And, alternately, as  is to , so is  to . []
And the sides are proportional about equal angles, namely the angles , ; therefore the triangle  is similar to the triangle . []

Again, since, as  is to , so is  to , and they are about equal angles, namely the angles , , inasmuch as, whatever part the angle  is of the four right angles at the centre , the same part also is the angle  of the four right angles at the centre ; since then the sides are proportional about equal angles, therefore the triangle  is similar to the triangle . []

Again, since it was proved that, as  is to , so is  to , while  is equal to , and  to , therefore, as  is to , so is  to ; and the sides are proportional about equal angles, namely the angles , , for they are right; therefore the triangle  is similar to the triangle . []
And since, owing to the similarity of the triangles , , as  is to , so is  to , and, owing to the similarity of the triangles , , as  is to , so is  to , therefore, , as  is to , so is  to . []
Again since, owing to the similarity of the triangles , , as  is to , so is  to , and, owing to the similarity of the triangles , , as  is to , so is  to ; therefore, , as  is to , so is  to . []
But it was also proved that, as  is to , so is  to .
Therefore, , as  is to , so is  to . []
Therefore in the triangles ,  the sides are proportional; therefore the triangles ,  are equiangular; [] hence they are also similar. []

Therefore the pyramid of which the triangle  is the base and the point  the vertex is also similar to the pyramid of which the triangle  is the base and the point  the vertex, for they are contained by similar planes equal in multitude. []
But similar pyramids which have triangular bases are to one another in the triplicate ratio of their corresponding sides. []
Therefore the pyramid  has to the pyramid  the ratio triplicate of that which  has to .

Similarly, by joining straight lines from , , , , ,  to , and from , , , , ,  to , and setting up on each of the triangles pyramids which have the same vertex with the cones, we can prove that each of the similarly arranged pyramids will also have to each similarly arranged pyramid the ratio triplicate of that which the corresponding side  has to the corresponding side , that is, which  has to .

And, as one of the antecedents is to one of the consequents, so are all the antecedents to all the consequents; [] therefore also, as the pyramid  is to the pyramid , so is the whole pyramid of which the polygon  is the base and the point  the vertex to the whole pyramid of which the polygon  is the base and the point  the vertex; hence also the pyramid of which  is the base and the point  the vertex has to the pyramid of which the polygon  is the base and the point  the vertex the ratio triplicate of that which  has to .

But, by hypothesis, the cone of which the circle 
       is the base and the point  the vertex has also to the solid  the ratio triplicate of that which  has to ; therefore, as the cone of which the circle  is the base and the point  the vertex is to the solid , so is the pyramid of which the polygon  is the base and  the vertex to the pyramid of which the polygon  is the base and the point  the vertex; therefore, alternately, as the cone of which the circle  is the base and  the vertex is to the pyramid contained in it of which the polygon  is the base and  the vertex, so is the solid  to the pyramid of which the polygon  is the base and  the vertex. []

p: But the said cone is greater than the pyramid in it; for it encloses it.

p.#text: Therefore the solid  is also greater than the pyramid of which the polygon  is the base and  the vertex.

p: But it is also less: which is impossible.

p.#text: Therefore the cone of which the circle  is the base and  the vertex has not to any solid less than the cone of which the circle  is the base and the point  the vertex the ratio triplicate of that which  has to :
Similarly we can prove that neither has the cone  to any solid less than the cone  the ratio triplicate of that which  has to .
I say next that neither has the cone  to any solid greater than the cone  the ratio triplicate of that which  has to .
For, if possible, let it have that ratio to a greater solid .
Therefore, inversely, the solid  has to the cone  the ratio triplicate of that which  has to .
But, as the solid  is to the cone , so is the cone  to some solid less than the cone .
Therefore the cone  also has to some solid less than the cone  the ratio triplicate of that which  has to : which was proved impossible.
Therefore the cone  has not to any solid greater than the cone  the ratio triplicate of that which  has to .
But it was proved that neither has it this ratio to a less solid than the cone .
Therefore the cone  has to the cone  the ratio triplicate of that which  has to .

But, as the cone is to the cone, so is the cylinder to the cylinder, for the cylinder which is on the same base as the cone and of equal height with it is triple of the cone; [] therefore the cylinder also has to the cylinder the ratio triplicate of that which  has to .

p: Therefore etc. Q. E. D.

hi.#text: If a cylinder be cut by a plane which is parallel to its opposite planes, then, as the cylinder is to the cylinder, so will the axis be to the axis.

p.#text: For let the cylinder  be cut by the plane  which is parallel to the opposite planes , , and let the plane  meet the axis at the point ; I say that, as the cylinder  is to the cylinder , so is the axis  to the axis .

For let the axis  be produced in both directions to the points , , and let there be set out any number whatever of axes ,  equal to the axis , and any number whatever ,  equal to ; and let the cylinder  on the axis  be conceived of which the circles ,  are the bases.
Let planes be carried through the points ,  parallel to ,  and to the bases of the cylinder , and let them produce the circles ,  about the centres , .
Then, since the axes , ,  are equal to one another, therefore the cylinders , ,  are to one another as their bases. []
But the bases are equal; therefore the cylinders , ,  are also equal to one another.

Since then the axes , ,  are equal to one another, and the cylinders , ,  are also equal to one another, and the multitude of the former is equal to the multitude of the latter, therefore, whatever multiple the axis  is of the axis , the same multiple also will the cylinder  be of the cylinder .
For the same reason, whatever multiple the axis  is of the axis , the same multiple also is the cylinder  of the cylinder .

And, if the axis  is equal to the axis , the cylinder  will also be equal to the cylinder , if the axis is greater than the axis, the cylinder will also be greater than the cylinder, and if less, less.

Thus, there being four magnitudes, the axes ,  and the cylinders , , there have been taken equimultiples of the axis  and of the cylinder , namely the axis  and the cylinder , and equimultiples of the axis  and of the cylinder , namely the axis  and the cylinder ; and it has been proved that, if the axis  is in excess of the axis , the cylinder  is also in excess of the cylinder , if equal, equal, and if less, less.
Therefore, as the axis  is to the axis , so is the cylinder  to the cylinder . [] Q. E. D.

hi.#text: Cones and cylinders which are on equal bases are to one another as their heights.

p.#text: For let ,  be cylinders on equal bases, the circles , ; I say that, as the cylinder  is to the cylinder , so is the axis  to the axis .
For let the axis  be produced to the point , let  be made equal to the axis , and let the cylinder  be conceived about  as axis.
Since then the cylinders ,  are of the same height, they are to one another as their bases. []
But the bases are equal to one another; therefore the cylinders ,  are also equal.
And, since the cylinder  has been cut by the plane  which is parallel to its opposite planes, therefore, as the cylinder  is to the cylinder , so is the axis  to the axis . []
But the cylinder  is equal to the cylinder , and the axis  to the axis ; therefore, as the cylinder  is to the cylinder , so is the axis  to the axis .
But, as the cylinder  is to the cylinder , so is the cone  to the cone . []
Therefore also, as the axis  is to the axis , so is the cone  to the cone  and the cylinder  to the cylinder . Q. E. D.

div3.head: PROPOSITION 15.

hi.#text: In equal cones and cylinders the bases are reciprocally proportional to the heights; and those cones and cylinders in which the bases are reciprocally proportional to the heights are equal.

p.#text: Let there be equal cones and cylinders of which the circles ,  are the bases; let ,  be the diameters of the bases, and ,  the axes, which are also the heights of the cones or cylinders; let the cylinders ,  be completed.
I say that in the cylinders ,  the bases are reciprocally proportional to the heights, that is, as the base  is to the base , so is the height  to the height .
For the height  is either equal to the height  or not equal.

p: First, let it be equal.

p.#text: Now the cylinder  is also equal to the cylinder .
But cones and cylinders which are of the same height are to one another as their bases; [] therefore the base  is also equal to the base .
Hence also, reciprocally, as the base  is to the base , so is the height  to the height .

Next, let the height  not be equal to , but let  be greater; from the height  let  be cut off equal to , through the point  let the cylinder  be cut by the plane  parallel to the planes of the circles , , and let the cylinder  be conceived erected from the circle  as base and with height .
Now, since the cylinder  is equal to the cylinder , therefore, as the cylinder  is to the cylinder , so is the cylinder  to the cylinder . []

But, as the cylinder  is to the cylinder , so is the base  to the base , for the cylinders ,  are of the same height; [] and, as the cylinder  is to the cylinder , so is the height  to the height , for the cylinder  has been cut by a plane which is parallel to its opposite planes. []
Therefore also, as the base  is to the base , so is the height  to the height . []
But the height  is equal to the height ; therefore, as the base  is to the base , so is the height  to the height .
Therefore in the cylinders ,  the bases are reciprocally proportional to the heights.

Next, in the cylinders ,  let the bases be reciprocally proportional to the heights, that is, as the base  is to the base , so let the height  be to the height ; I say that the cylinder  is equal to the cylinder .

For, with the same construction, since, as the base  is to the base , so is the height  to the height , while the height  is equal to the height , therefore, as the base  is to the base , so is the height  to the height

But, as the base  is to the base , so is the cylinder  to the cylinder , for they are of the same height; [] and, as the height  is to , so is the cylinder  to the cylinder ; [] therefore, as the cylinder  is to the cylinder , so is the cylinder  to the cylinder . []
Therefore the cylinder  is equal to the cylinder . []

p: And the same is true for the cones also. Q. E. D.

hi.#text: Given two circles about the same centre
to inscribe in the greater circle an equilateral polygon with an even number of sides which does not touch the lesser circle.

p.#text: Let ,  be the two given circles about the same centre ; thus it is required to inscribe in the greater circle  an equilateral polygon with an even number of sides which does not touch the circle .
For let the straight line  be drawn through the centre , and from the point  let  be drawn at right angles to the straight line  and carried through to ; therefore  touches the circle . []
Then, bisecting the circumference , bisecting the half of it, and doing this continually, we shall leave a circumference less than . []
Let such be left, and let it be ; from  let  be drawn perpendicular to  and carried through to , and let ,  be joined; therefore  is equal to . [, ]
Now, since  is parallel to , and  touches the circle , therefore  does not touch the circle ; therefore ,  are far from touching the circle .

If then we fit into the circle  straight lines equal to the straight line  and placed continuously, there will be inscribed in the circle  an equilateral polygon with an even number of sides which does not touch the lesser circle . Q. E. F.

div3.head: PROPOSITION 17.

hi.#text: Given two spheres about the same centre
to inscribe in the greater sphere a polyhedral solid which does not touch the lesser sphere at its surface.

p.#text: Let two spheres be conceived about the same centre ; thus it is required to inscribe in the greater sphere a polyhedral solid which does not touch the lesser sphere at its surface.

Let the spheres be cut by any plane through the centre; then the sections will be circles, inasmuch as the sphere was produced by the diameter remaining fixed and the semicircle being carried round it; [] hence, in whatever position we conceive the semicircle to be, the plane carried through it will produce a circle on the circumference of the sphere.

And it is manifest that this circle is the greatest possible, inasmuch as the diameter of the sphere, which is of course the diameter both of the semicircle and of the circle, is greater than all the straight lines drawn across in the circle or the sphere.

Let then  be the circle in the greater sphere, and  the circle in the lesser sphere; let two diameters in them, , , be drawn at right angles to one another; then, given the two circles ,  about the same centre, let there be inscribed in the greater circle  an equilateral polygon with an even number of sides which does not touch the lesser circle , let , , 
        be its sides in the quadrant . let  be joined and carried through to , let  be set up from the point  at right angles to the plane of the circle , and let it meet the surface of the sphere at , and through  and each of the straight lines ,  let planes be carried; they will then make greatest circles on the surface of the sphere, for the reason stated.
Let them make such, and in them let ,  be the semicircles on , .

Now, since  is at right angles to the plane of the circle , therefore all the planes through  are also at right angles to the plane of the circle ; [] hence the semicircles ,  are also at right angles to the plane of the circle .
And, since the semicircles , ,  are equal, for they are on the equal diameters , , therefore the quadrants , ,  are also equal to one another.
Therefore there are as many straight lines in the quadrants ,  equal to the straight lines , , ,  as there are sides of the polygon in the quadrant .

Let them be inscribed, and let them be , , ,  and , , , , let , ,  be joined, and from ,  let perpendiculars be drawn to the plane of the circle ; [] these will fall on , , the common sections of the planes, inasmuch as the planes of ,  are also at right angles to the plane of the circle . [cf. ]
Let them so fall, and let them be , , and let  be joined.
Now since, in the equal semicircles , , equal straight lines ,  have been cut off, and the perpendiculars ,  have been drawn, therefore  is equal to , and  to . [, ]
But the whole  is also equal to the whole ; therefore the remainder  is also equal to the remainder ; therefore, as  is to , so is  to ; therefore  is parallel to . []
And, since each of the straight lines ,  is at right angles to the plane of the circle , therefore  is parallel to . []
But it was also proved equal to it; therefore ,  are also equal and parallel. []
And, since  is parallel to , while  is parallel to , therefore  is also parallel to . []

And ,  join their extremities; therefore the quadrilateral  is in one plane, inasmuch as, if two straight lines be parallel, and points be taken at random on each of them, the straight line joining the points is in the same plane with the parallels. []
For the same reason each of the quadrilaterals ,  is also in one plane.
But the triangle  is also in one plane. []

If then we conceive straight lines joined from the points , , , , ,  to , there will be constructed a certain polyhedral solid figure between the circumferences , , consisting of pyramids of which the quadrilaterals , ,  and the triangle  are the bases and the point  the vertex.

And, if we make the same construction in the case of each of the sides , ,  as in the case of , and further in the case of the remaining three quadrants, there will be constructed a certain polyhedral figure inscribed in the sphere and contained by pyramids, of which the said quadrilaterals and the triangle , and the others corresponding to them, are the bases and the point  the vertex.
I say that the said polyhedron will not touch the lesser sphere at the surface on which the circle  is.
Let  be drawn from the point  perpendicular to the plane of the quadrilateral , and let it meet the plane at the point ; [] let ,  be joined.
Then, since  is at right angles to the plane of the quadrilateral , therefore it is also at right angles to all the straight lines which meet it and are in the plane of the quadrilateral. []
Therefore  is at right angles to each of the straight lines , .
And, since  is equal to , the square on  is also equal to the square on .
And the squares on ,  are equal to the square on , for the angle at  is right; [] and the squares on ,  are equal to the square on . [.]
Therefore the squares on ,  are equal to the squares on , .
Let the square on  be subtracted from each; therefore the remainder, the square on , is equal to the remainder, the square on ; therefore  is equal to .
Similarly we can prove that the straight lines joined from  to ,  are equal to each of the straight lines , .
Therefore the circle described with centre  and distance one of the straight lines ,  will pass through ,  also, and  will be a quadrilateral in a circle.
Now, since  is greater than , while  is equal to , therefore  is greater than .
But  is equal to each of the straight lines , ; therefore each of the straight lines ,  is greater than .
And, since  is a quadrilateral in a circle, and , ,  are equal, and  less, and  is the radius of the circle, therefore the square on  is greater than double of the square on .
Let  be drawn from  perpendicular to .

Then, since  is less than double of , and, as  is to , so is the rectangle ,  to the rectangle , , if a square be described upon  and the parallelogram on  be completed, then the rectangle ,  is also less than double of the rectangle , .
And, if  be joined, the rectangle ,  is equal to the square on , and the rectangle ,  equal to the square on ; [, ] therefore the square on  is less than double of the square on .
But the square on  is greater than double of the square on ; therefore the square on  is greater than the square on .
And, since  is equal to , the square on  is equal to the square on .

And the squares on ,  are equal to the square on , and the squares on ,  equal to the square on ; [] therefore the squares on ,  are equal to the squares on , , and of these the square on  is greater than the square on ; therefore the remainder, the square on , is less than the square on .
Therefore  is greater than ; therefore  is much greater than .
And  is the perpendicular on one base of the polyhedron, and  on the surface of the lesser sphere; hence the polyhedron will not touch the lesser sphere on its surface.

p: Therefore, given two spheres about the same centre, a polyhedral solid has been inscribed in the greater sphere which does not touch the lesser sphere at its surface. Q. E. F.

div4.head: PORISM.

p.#text: But if in another sphere also a polyhedral solid be inscribed similar to the solid in the sphere , the polyhedral solid in the sphere  has to the polyhedral solid in the other sphere the ratio triplicate of that which the diameter of the sphere  has to the diameter of the other sphere.

p: For, the solids being divided into their pyramids similar in multitude and arrangement, the pyramids will be similar.

p.#text: But similar pyramids are to one another in the triplicate ratio of their corresponding sides; [] therefore the pyramid of which the quadrilateral  is the base, and the point  the vertex, has to the similarly arranged pyramid in the other sphere the ratio triplicate of that which the corresponding side has to the corresponding side, that is, of that which the radius  of the sphere about  as centre has to the radius of the other sphere.

Similarly also each pyramid of those in the sphere about  as centre has to each similarly arranged pyramid of those in the other sphere the ratio triplicate of that which  has to the radius of the other sphere.

And, as one of the antecedents is to one of the consequents, so are all the antecedents to all the consequents; [] hence the whole polyhedral solid in the sphere about  as centre has to the whole polyhedral solid in the other sphere the ratio triplicate of that which  has to the radius of the other sphere, that is, of that which the diameter  has to the diameter of the other sphere. Q. E. D.

div3.head: PROPOSITION 18.

hi.#text: Spheres are to one another in the triplicate ratio of their respective diameters.

p.#text: Let the spheres ,  be conceived, and let ,  be their diameters; I say that the sphere  has to the sphere  the ratio triplicate of that which  has to .

For, if the sphere  has not to the sphere  the ratio triplicate of that which  has to , then the sphere  will have either to some less sphere than the sphere , or to a greater, the ratio triplicate of that which  has to .

First, let it have that ratio to a less sphere , let  be conceived about the same centre with , let there be inscribed in the greater sphere  a polyhedral solid which does not touch the lesser sphere  at its surface, [] and let there also be inscribed in the sphere  a polyhedral solid similar to the polyhedral solid in the sphere ; therefore the polyhedral solid in  has to the polyhedral solid in  the ratio triplicate of that which  has to . []

But the sphere  also has to the sphere  the ratio triplicate of that which  has to ; therefore, as the sphere  is to the sphere , so is the polyhedral solid in the sphere  to the polyhedral solid in the sphere ; and, alternately, as the sphere  is to the polyhedron in it, so is the sphere  to the polyhedral solid in the sphere . []
But the sphere  is greater than the polyhedron in it; therefore the sphere  is also greater than the polyhedron in the sphere .

p: But it is also less, for it is enclosed by it.

p.#text: Therefore the sphere  has not to a less sphere than the sphere  the ratio triplicate of that which the diameter  has to .
Similarly we can prove that neither has the sphere  to a less sphere than the sphere  the ratio triplicate of that which  has to .
I say next that neither has the sphere  to any greater sphere than the sphere  the ratio triplicate of that which  has to .
For, if possible, let it have that ratio to a greater, ; therefore, inversely, the sphere  has to the sphere  the ratio triplicate of that which the diameter  has to the diameter .
But, inasmuch as  is greater than , therefore, as the sphere  is to the sphere , so is the sphere  to some less sphere than the sphere , as was before proved. []
Therefore the sphere  also has to some less sphere than the sphere  the ratio triplicate of that which  has to : which was proved impossible.
Therefore the sphere  has not to any sphere greater than the sphere  the ratio triplicate of that which  has to .

p: But it was proved that neither has it that ratio to a less sphere.

p.#text: Therefore the sphere  has to the sphere  the ratio triplicate of that which  has to . Q. E. D.

p.title: Geschichte der Mathematik
p.#text: I have already given, in the note to , the evidence upon which the construction of the five regular solids is attributed to the Pythagoreans. Some of them, the cube, the tetrahedron (which is nothing but a pyramid), and the octahedron (which is only a double pyramid with a square base), cannot but have been known to the Egyptians. And it appears that dodecahedra have been found, of bronze or other material, which may belong to periods earlier than Pythagoras' time by some centuries (for references see Cantor's  I_{3}, pp. 175-6).

quote: the five so-called Platonic figures, which however do not belong to Plato, three of the aforesaid five figures being due to the Pythagoreans, namely the cube, the pyramid and the dodecahedron, while the octahedron and the icosahedron are due to Theaetetus.
first wrote on the five solids as they are called.
p.#text:
It is true that the author of the scholium No. I to Eucl. XIII. says that the Book is about 
 This statement (taken probably from Geminus) may perhaps rest on the fact that Theaetetus was the first to write at any length about the two last-mentioned solids. We are told indeed by Suidas (S. V. ) that Theaetetus 
 This no doubt means that Theaetetus was the first to write a complete and systematic treatise on all the regular solids; it does not exclude the possibility that Hippasus or others had already written on the dodecahedron. The fact that Theaetetus wrote upon the regular solids agrees very well with the evidence which we possess of his contributions to the theory of irrationals, the connexion between which and the investigation of the regular solids is seen in Euclid's Book XIII.

title: Solid Loci
Comparison of the five regular solids
Elements
p.#text:
Theaetetus flourished about 380 B.C., and his work on the regular solids was soon followed by another, that of Aristaeus, an elder contemporary of Euclid, who also wrote an important book on , i.e. on conics treated as loci. This Aristaeus (known as 
) wrote in the period about 320 B.C. We hear of his  from Hypsicles (2nd cent. B.C.), the writer of the short book commonly included in the editions of the  as Book XIV. Hypsicles gives in this Book some six propositions supplementing Eucl. XIII.; and he introduces the second of the propositions (Heiberg's Euclid, Vol. v. p. 6) as follows:

hi.#text: The same circle circumscribes both the pentagon of the dodecahedron and the triangle of the icosahedron when both are inscribed in the same sphere

quote.title: Comparison of the five figures
quote.#text: . This is proved by Aristaeus in the book entitled .

p.title: Greek Geometry from Thales to Euclid
p.#text: Hypsicles proceeds (pp. 7 sqq.) to give a proof of this theorem. Allman pointed out (, 1889, pp. 201-2) that this proof depends on eight theorems, six of which appear in Euclid's Book XIII. (in Propositions , , , ); two other propositions not mentioned by Allman are also used, namely . This seems, as Allman says, to confirm the inference of Bretschneider (p. 171) that, as Aristaeus' work was the newest and latest in which, before Euclid's time, this subject was treated, we have in Eucl. XIII. at least a partial recapitulation of the contents of the treatise of Aristaeus.

quote.title: Comparison of the dodecahedron with the icosahedron
quote.#text: But it is proved by Apollonius in the second edition of his  that, as the surface of the dodecahedron is to the surface of the icosahedron [inscribed in the same sphere], so is the dodecahedron itself [i.e. its volume] to the icosahedron, because the perpendicular is the same from the centre of the sphere to the pentagon of the dodecahedron and to the triangle of the icosahedron.

p.#text: After Euclid, Apollonius wrote on the comparison of the dodecahedron and the icosahedron inscribed in one and the same sphere. This we also learn from Hypsicles, who says in the next words following those about Aristaeus above quoted:

And, since  is double of , while  is equal to , and  to , therefore  is also double of .

But ,  are also double of .

But  was also proved equal to ; therefore the whole square  is equal to the gnomon .

p: Therefore etc. Q. E. D.

p: I say next that it is also comprehended in the given sphere.

p.#text: For, since  is equal to , while  is common, and they contain right angles, therefore the base  is equal to the base . []
And, since the angle  is right, for it is in a semicircle, [] therefore the square on  is double of the square on . []
Again, since  is equal to ,  is double of .
But, as  is to , so is the square on  to the square on ; therefore the square on  is double of the square on .
But the square on  was also proved double of the square on .
And the square on  is equal to the square on , for  was made equal to .
Therefore the square on  is also equal to the square on ; therefore  is equal to .
And  is the diameter of the given sphere; therefore  is equal to the diameter of the given sphere.

p: Therefore the octahedron has been comprehended in the given sphere, and it has been demonstrated at the same time that the square on the diameter of the sphere is double of the square on the side of the octahedron. Q. E. D.

div3.head: PROPOSITION 15.

hi.#text: To construct a cube and comprehend it in a sphere
like the pyramid; and to prove that the square on the diameter of the sphere is triple of the square on the side of the cube.

p.#text: Let the diameter  of the given sphere be set out, and let it be cut at  so that  is double of ; let the semicircle  be described on , let  be drawn from  at right angles to , and let  be joined; let the square  having its side equal to  be set out, from , , ,  let , , ,  be drawn at right angles to the plane of the square , from , , ,  let , , ,  respectively be cut off equal to one of the straight lines , , , , and let , , ,  be joined; therefore the cube  has been constructed which is contained by six equal squares.

p: It is then required to comprehend it in the given sphere, and to prove that the square on the diameter of the sphere is triple of the square on the side of the cube.

p.#text: For let ,  be joined.
Then, since the angle  is right, because  is also at right angles to the plane  and of course to the straight line  also, [] therefore the semicircle described on  will also pass through the point .

Again, since  is at right angles to each of the straight lines , ,  is also at right angles to the plane ; hence also, if we join ,  will be at right angles to ; and for this reason again the semicircle described on  will also pass through .

p: Similarly it will also pass through the remaining angular points of the cube.

p.#text: If then,  remaining fixed, the semicircle be carried round and restored to the same position from which it began to be moved, the cube will be comprehended in a sphere.

p: I say next that it is also comprehended in the given sphere.

But  is equal to ; therefore the square on  is double of the square on ; hence the squares on , , that is the square on  [], is triple of the square on .
And, since  is triple of , while, as  is to , so is the square on  to the square on , therefore the square on  is triple of the square on .
But the square on  was also proved triple of the square on .
And  was made equal to ; therefore  is also equal to .
And  is the diameter of the given sphere; therefore  is also equal to the diameter of the given sphere.

p: Therefore the cube has been comprehended in the given sphere; and it has been demonstrated at the same time that the square on the diameter of the sphere is triple of the square on the side of the cube. Q. E. D.

div3.head: PROPOSITION 16.

hi.#text: To construct an icosahedron and comprehend it in a sphere
like the aforesaid figures; and to prove that the side of the icosahedron is the irrational straight line called minor.

p.#text: Let the diameter  of the given sphere be set out, and let it be cut at  so that  is quadruple of , let the semicircle  be described on , let the straight line  be drawn from  at right angles to , and let  be joined;  let the circle  be set out and let its radius be equal to , let the equilateral and equiangular pentagon  be inscribed in the circle , let the circumferences , , , ,  be bisected at the points , , , , , and let , , , , ,  be joined.
Therefore the pentagon  is also equilateral, and the straight line  belongs to a decagon.

Now from the points , , , ,  let the straight lines , , , ,  be set up at right angles to the plane of the circle, and let them be equal to the radius of the circle , let , , , , , , , , , , , , , ,  be joined.

Therefore  is equal and parallel to .
But  belongs to an equilateral pentagon; therefore  also belongs to the equilateral pentagon inscribed in the circle .
For the same reason each of the straight lines , , ,  also belongs to the equilateral pentagon inscribed in the circle ; therefore the pentagon  is equilateral.

And, since  belongs to a hexagon, and  to a decagon, and the angle  is right, therefore  belongs to a pentagon; for the square on the side of the pentagon is equal to the square on the side of the hexagon and the square on the side of the decagon inscribed in the same circle. []
For the same reason  is also a side of a pentagon.
But  also belongs to a pentagon; therefore the triangle  is equilateral.
For the same reason each of the triangles , , ,  is also equilateral.
And, since each of the straight lines ,  was proved to belong to a pentagon, and  also belongs to a pentagon, therefore the triangle  is equilateral.
For the same reason each of the triangles , , ,  is also equilateral.

Let the centre of the circle  the point , be taken; from  let  be set up at right angles to the plane of the circle, let it be produced in the other direction, as , let there be cut off , the side of a hexagon, and each of the straight lines , , being sides of a decagon, and let , , , , , ,  be joined.
Now, since each of the straight lines ,  is at right angles to the plane of the circle, therefore  is parallel to . []
But they are also equal; therefore ,  are also equal and parallel. []
But  belongs to a hexagon; therefore  also belongs to a hexagon.
And, since  belongs to a hexagon, and  to a decagon, and the angle  is right, therefore  belongs to a pentagon. []
For the same reason  also belongs to a pentagon, inasmuch as, if we join , , they will be equal and opposite, and , being a radius, belongs to a hexagon; [] therefore  also belongs to a hexagon.
But  belongs to a decagon, and the angle  is right; therefore  belongs to a pentagon. []
But  also belongs to a pentagon; therefore the triangle  is equilateral.
For the same reason each of the remaining triangles of which the straight lines , , ,  are the bases, and the point  the vertex, is also equilateral.
Again, since  belongs to a hexagon, and  to a decagon, and the angle  is right, therefore  belongs to a pentagon. []
For the same reason, if we join , which belongs to a hexagon,  is also inferred to belong to a pentagon.
But  also belongs to a pentagon; therefore the triangle  is equilateral.
Similarly it can be proved that each of the remaining triangles of which , , ,  are the bases, and the point  the vertex, is also equilateral.

p: Therefore an icosahedron has been constructed which is contained by twenty equilateral triangles.
It is next required to comprehend it in the given sphere, and to prove that the side of the icosahedron is the irrational straight line called minor.

p.#text: For, since  belongs to a hexagon, and  to a decagon, therefore  has been cut in extreme and mean ratio at , and  is its greater segment; [] therefore, as  is to , so is  to .
But  is equal to , and  to ; therefore, as  is to , so is  to .
And the angles ,  are right; therefore, if we join the straight line , the angle  will be right because of the similarity of the triangles , .
For the same reason, since, as  is to , so is  to , and  is equal to , and  to , therefore, as  is to , so is  to .
And for this reason again, if we join , the angle at  will be right; [] therefore the semicircle described on  will also pass through . []

And if,  remaining fixed, the semicircle be carried round and restored to the same position from which it began to be moved, it will also pass through  and the remaining angular points of the icosahedron, and the icosahedron will have been comprehended in a sphere.

p: I say next that it is also comprehended in the given sphere.

p.#text: For let  be bisected at .

Then, since the straight line  has been cut in extreme and mean ratio at , and  is its lesser segment, therefore the square on  added to the half of the greater segment, that is , is five times the square on the half of the greater segment; [] therefore the square on  is five times the square on .
And  is double of , and  double of ; therefore the square on  is five times the square on .
And, since  is quadruple of , therefore  is five times .
But, as  is to , so is the square on  to the square on ; [, ] therefore the square on  is five times the square on .
But the square on  was also proved to be five times the square on .
And  is equal to , for each of them is equal to the radius of the circle ; therefore  is also equal to .
And  is the diameter of the given sphere; therefore  is also equal to the diameter of the given sphere.
Therefore the icosahedron has been comprehended in the given sphere

p: I say next that the side of the icosahedron is the irrational straight line called minor.

p.#text: For, since the diameter of the sphere is rational, and the square on it is five times the square on the radius of the circle , therefore the radius of the circle  is also rational; hence its diameter is also rational.
But, if an equilateral pentagon be inscribed in a circle which has its diameter rational, the side of the pentagon is the irrational straight line called minor. []
And the side of the pentagon  is the side of the icosahedron.

p: Therefore the side of the icosahedron is the irrational straight line called minor.

div4.head: PORISM.
div4.p: From this it is manifest that the square on the diameter of the sphere is five times the square on the radius of the circle from which the icosahedron has been described, and that the diameter of the sphere is composed of the side of the hexagon and two of the sides of the decagon inscribed in the same circle. Q. E. D.

div3.head: PROPOSITION 17.

hi.#text: To construct a dodecahedron and comprehend it in a sphere
like the aforesaid figures, and to prove that the side of the dodecahedron is the irrational straight line called apotome.

p.#text: Let , , two planes of the aforesaid cube at right angles to one another, be set out, let the sides , , , , , ,  be bisected at , , , , , ,  respectively, let , , ,  be joined, let the straight lines , ,  be cut in extreme and mean ratio at the points , ,  respectively, and let , ,  be their greater segments; from the points , ,  let , ,  be set up at right angles to the planes of the cube towards the outside of the cube, let them be made equal to , , , and let , , , ,  be joined.
