But the square on  is equal to the squares on , ; therefore the square on  is quadruple of the square on ; therefore  is double of .
But  is also double of , inasmuch as  is also double of , that is, of ; therefore  is equal to .
Similarly it can be proved that each of the straight lines , ,  is also equal to each of the straight lines , .
Therefore the pentagon  is equilateral.

p: I say next that it is also in one plane.

p.#text: For let  be drawn from  parallel to each of the straight lines ,  and towards the outside of the cube, and let ,  be joined; I say that  is a straight line.
For, since  has been cut in extreme and mean ratio at , and  is its greater segment, therefore, as  is to , so is  to .
But  is equal to , and  to each of the straight lines , ; therefore, as  is to , so is  to .
And  is parallel to , for each of them is at right angles to the plane ; [] and  is parallel to , for each of them is at right angles to the plane . [.]

But if two triangles, as , , which have two sides proportional to two sides be placed together at one angle so that their corresponding sides are also parallel, the remaining straight lines will be in a straight line; [] therefore  is in a straight line with .
But every straight line is in one plane; [] therefore the pentagon  is in one plane.

p: I say next that it is also equiangular.

p.#text: For, since the straight line  has been cut in extreme and mean ratio at , and  is the greater segment, while  is equal to , therefore  has also been cut in extreme and mean ratio at , and  is the greater segment; [] therefore the squares on ,  are triple of the square on . []
But  is equal to , and  to ; therefore the squares on ,  are triple of the square on ; hence the squares on , ,  are quadruple of the square on .
But the square on  is equal to the squares on , ; therefore the squares on , , that is, the square on  for the angle  is rightis quadruple of the square on ; therefore  is double of .
But  is also double of ; therefore  is equal to .
And, since the two sides ,  are equal to the two sides , , and the base  is equal to the base , therefore the angle  is equal to the angle . []
Similarly we can prove that the angle  is also equal to the angle ; therefore the three angles , ,  are equal to one another.
But if in an equilateral pentagon three angles are equal to one another, the pentagon will be equiangular, [] therefore the pentagon  is equiangular.
And it was also proved equilateral; therefore the pentagon  is equilateral and equiangular, and it is on one side  of the cube.

p: Therefore, if we make the same construction in the case of each of the twelve sides of the cube, a solid figure will have been constructed which is contained by twelve equilateral and equiangular pentagons, and which is called a dodecahedron.
It is then required to comprehend it in the given sphere, and to prove that the side of the dodecahedron is the irrational straight line called apotome.

p.#text: For let  be produced, and let the produced straight line be ; therefore  meets the diameter of the cube, and they bisect one another, for this has been proved in the last theorem but one of the eleventh book. []
Let them cut at ; therefore  is the centre of the sphere which comprehends the cube, and  is half of the side of the cube.
Let  be joined.
Now, since the straight line  has been cut in extreme and mean ratio at , and  is its greater segment, therefore the squares on ,  are triple of the square on . []
But  is equal to , inasmuch as  is also equal to , and  to .
But further  is also equal to , since it is also equal to ; therefore the squares on ,  are triple of the square on .
But the square on  is equal to the squares on , ; therefore the square on  is triple of the square on .

But the square on the radius of the sphere which comprehends the cube is also triple of the square on the half of the side of the cube, for it has previously been shown how to construct a cube and comprehend it in a sphere, and to prove that the square on the diameter of the sphere is triple of the square on the side of the cube. []
But, if whole is so related to whole, so is half to half also; and  is half of the side of the cube; therefore  is equal to the radius of the sphere which comprehends the cube.
And  is the centre of the sphere which comprehends the cube; therefore the point  is on the surface of the sphere.

p: Similarly we can prove that each of the remaining angles of the dodecahedron is also on the surface of the sphere; therefore the dodecahedron has been comprehended in the given sphere.
I say next that the side of the dodecahedron is the irrational straight line called apotome.

p.#text: For since, when  has been cut in extreme and mean ratio,  is the greater segment, and, when  has been cut in extreme and mean ratio,  is the greater segment, therefore, when the whole  is cut in extreme and mean ratio,  is the greater segment.
[Thus, since, as  is to , so is  to , the same is true of the doubles also, for parts have the same ratio as their equimultiples; [] therefore as  is to , so is  to the sum of , .
But  is greater than ; therefore  is also greater than the sum of , ; therefore  has been cut in extreme and mean ratio, and  is its greater segment.]
But  is equal to ; therefore, when  is cut in extreme and mean ratio,  is the greater segment.
And, since the diameter of the sphere is rational, and the square on it is triple of the square on the side of the cube, therefore , being a side of the cube, is rational.

p: [But if a rational line be cut in extreme and mean ratio, each of the segments is an irrational apotome.]

p.#text: Therefore , being a side of the dodecahedron, is an irrational apotome. []

div4.head: PORISM.
div4.p: From this it is manifest that, when the side of the cube is cut in extreme and mean ratio, the greater segment is the side of the dodecahedron. Q. E. D.

div3.head: PROPOSITION 18.

But  is equal to ; therefore the square on  is five times the square on .

Therefore  is triple of ; therefore the square on  is nine times the square on .
But the square on  is five times the square on ; therefore the square on  is greater than the square on ; therefore  is greater than .
Let  be made equal to , from  let  be drawn at right angles to , and let  be joined.
Now, since the square on  is five times the square on , and  is double of , and  double of , therefore the square on  is five times the square on .

And  is the diameter of the sphere; therefore  is the radius of the circle from which the icosahedron has been described; therefore  is a side of the hexagon in the said circle. []

And, since the diameter of the sphere is made up of the side of the hexagon and two of the sides of the decagon inscribed in the same circle, [] and  is the diameter of the sphere, while  is a side of the hexagon, and  is equal to , therefore each of the straight lines ,  is a side of the decagon inscribed in the circle from which the icosahedron has been described.

And, since  belongs to a decagon, and  to a hexagon, for  is equal to , since it is also equal to , being the same distance from the centre, and each of the straight lines ,  is double of , therefore  belongs to a pentagon. []
But the side of the pentagon is the side of the icosahedron; [] therefore  belongs to the icosahedron.
Now, since  is a side of the cube, let it be cut in extreme and mean ratio at , and let  be the greater segment; therefore  is a side of the dodecahedron. []

And, since the square on the diameter of the sphere was proved to be one and a half times the square on the side  of the pyramid, double of the square on the side  of the octahedron and triple of the side  of the cube, therefore, of parts of which the square on the diameter of the sphere contains six, the square on the side of the pyramid contains four, the square on the side of the octahedron three, and the square on the side of the cube two.

p: Therefore the square on the side of the pyramid is fourthirds of the square on the side of the octahedron, and double of the square on the side of the cube; and the square on the side of the octahedron is one and a half times the square on the side of the cube.
The said sides, therefore, of the three figures, I mean the pyramid, the octahedron and the cube, are to one another in rational ratios.

p.#text: But the remaining two, I mean the side of the icosahedron and the side of the dodecahedron, are not in rational ratios either to one another or to the aforesaid sides; for they are irrational, the one being minor [] and the other an apotome [].
That the side  of the icosahedron is greater than the side  of the dodecahedron we can prove thus.
For, since the triangle  is equiangular with the triangle , [] proportionally, as  is to , so is  to . []

And, since the three straight lines are proportional, as the first is to the third, so is the square on the first to the square on the second; [, ] therefore, as  is to , so is the square on  to the square on ; therefore, inversely, as  is to , so is the square on  to the square on .
But  is triple of ; therefore the square on  is triple of the square on .
But the square on  is also quadruple of the square on , for  is double of ; therefore the square on  is greater than the square on ; therefore  is greater than ; therefore  is by far greater than .

And, when  is cut in extreme and mean ratio,  is the greater segment, inasmuch as  belongs to a hexagon, and  to a decagon; [] and, when  is cut in extreme and mean ratio,  is the greater segment; therefore  is greater than .
But  is equal to ; therefore  is greater than .
Therefore , which is a side of the icosahedron, is by far greater than  which is a side of the dodecahedron. Q. E. D.

hi.#text: can be constructed which is contained by equilateral and equiangular figures equal to one another.

p.#text: I say next that , ,

p: For a solid angle cannot be constructed with two triangles, or indeed planes.

p.#text: With three triangles the angle of the pyramid is constructed, with four the angle of the octahedron, and with five the angle of the icosahedron; but a solid angle cannot be formed by six equilateral and equiangular triangles placed together at one point, for, the angle of the equilateral triangle being two-thirds of a right angle, the six will be equal to four right angles: which is impossible, for any solid angle is contained by angles less than four right angles. []

p: For the same reason, neither can a solid angle be constructed by more than six plane angles.
By three squares the angle of the cube is contained, but by four it is impossible for a solid angle to be contained, for they will again be four right angles.

By three equilateral and equiangular pentagons the angle of the dodecahedron is contained; but by four such it is impossible for any solid angle to be contained, for, the angle of the equilateral pentagon being a right angle and a fifth, the four angles will be greater than four right angles: which is impossible.
Neither again will a solid angle be contained by other polygonal figures by reason of the same absurdity.
Therefore etc. Q. E. D.

hi.#text: the angle of the equilateral and equiangular pentagon is a right angle and a fifth

p.#text: But that  we must prove thus.
Let  be an equilateral and equiangular pentagon, let the circle  be circumscribed about it, let its centre  be taken, and let , , , ,  be joined.
Therefore they bisect the angles of the pentagon at , , , , .

And, since the angles at  are equal to four right angles and are equal, therefore one of them, as the angle , is one right angle less a fifth; therefore the remaining angles ,  consist of one right angle and a fifth.
But the angle  is equal to the angle ; therefore the whole angle  of the pentagon consists of one right angle and a fifth. Q. E. D.
